direction.raw_text: Norman steps carefully around the unseen body, crosses to the desk, starts going through Mary's handbag, in search of her car keys. He suddenly notices them lying on the desk, where he'd thrown them after parking her car. He picks up the keys, crosses the room, goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Norman pauses at the door, check cautiously, then hurry across the porch and into Mary's car. He circle-turns the car, so that its trunk is backed up to the turns porch, directly opposite Mary's door, as close as it can go. Then he alights, goes to the trunk, opens it with the key and, leaving the trunk lid raised, goes back into the cabin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a raised angle, we see Norman bend down and begin to wrap the shower curtain around the body. We see the edges of the curtain as they are raised and laid down again. Then he picks up the wrapped body, crosses to the door, uses his foot to pull the door open, and, leaving the door open behind him, goes quickly across the porch and gently lays the body in the trunk. He closes the lid then, but does not lock it. He comes back into the cabin, closes the door completely, flicks on the light. Again the newspaper is in the foreground. For a moment he pauses, closes his eyes against the realization of what he is doing, then quickly pushes all thoughts away, continues with his work. With the room lighted, he now proceeds to gather up all Mary's articles and toss them into the suitcase. He checks all drawers and the closet, gets down and checks under bed and bureau, goes into the bathroom, checks that room again, comes back into the bedroom, looks about carefully, spots Mary's handbag, throws even that into the suitcase, is finally satisfied that all traces of the girl are gone from the room. Then he closes Mary's suitcase, picks it up. With his free hand he picks up the pail, in which are the mop and the used towels. He crosses to the door, switches off the light with his shoulder, pulls open the door, starts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Norman stands in the doorway, he is suddenly and blindingly lit by the bright headlights of a passing car. The flash of the lights and the SOUND of the SPEEDING CAR are over in a flicker of a moment, but it takes a few seconds for Norman to regain his former tense composure. Then he goes to the car trunk, raises it with his foot, throws the suitcase and the pail into it, slams it shut. He pauses a moment, then realizes he has left the bathroom light on in Mary's cabin. He returns to cabin. As he enters, his eye is caught by the newspaper on the bedside table. He goes to it, takes the newspaper, and looks once again into the bathroom. His glance goes right over the toilet bowl. He turns out the lights, crosses the darkened cabin, goes out onto the porch. He reopens the trunk, tosses in the newspaper and closes it. He goes around and jumps into the car and starts away. We HOLD on the trunk, follow it for a while, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) The car pulls away from a CLOSE ANGLE on the trunk and as CAMERA HOLDS we see that we are now in a swamp area. It is quiet except for the irritating noises of night insects. Norman stops the car at the very edge of the swamp, turns off the lights, gets out, leaving door open. He looks at the swamp, seems doubtful of its ability to swallow up the car, realizes he has no choice. He leans into the car, releases the emergency brake, starts to push. The front of the car begins to roll into the swamp. Suddenly there is the LOW, THROBBING SOUND of a motor. Norman freezes, listens. The SOUND grows louder and Norman realizes it is an airplane flying overhead. The car is rolling quickly now. Norman jumps away, slams the door shut, stands tense. The SOUND of the plane overhead grows louder. Norman looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE BLACK SKY We see no plane. The SOUND of the motor is beginning to diminish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the relief in his face. He looks at the car. More than two-thirds of it have already sunk into the swamp. The trunk alone seems to hold poised above the sand and slime, as if refusing to go the rest of the way. Norman begins to panic, he steps dangerously close, pushes with his foot. And slowly the car sinks, until finally it is gone and we hear only the gentle plop of the swamp's final gulp, and see only the small after-bubble, like a visual burp. Norman waits a moment, then begins stamping out the tire marks, so obvious in the wet ground around the swamp. He stamps and drags his feet over the markings as we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP NORMAN standing on the porch of the motel, leaning against a post. He is staring out into the night, a look of guarded, casual innocence on his face, as if he were taking one last moment of peaceful night air before retiring. Then he glances down and CAMERA follows his gaze. A hose is lying on the ground outside Mary's cabin, its stream of water obliterating the tire marks. After a moment, Norman's hand comes into shot, picks up hose, places it in a new position. As CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see that the water from the hose has erased and rearranged the road markings so that it would be impossible to tell that a car had been parked here. After a short wait, Norman goes to the hose-faucet, turns it off, unscrews the hose. As he rolls the hose, he walks away from the spot, past the office, heading for the path that leads to the house. He goes up the path, pauses at the steps of the house, tosses the curled hose onto the lawn, goes up the steps and into the house. CAMERA FOLLOWS him in, PAUSES as he pauses at the foot of the stairs. Norman goes up the stairs. On the landing he stops. The door to his mother's room is closed. Lying in a heap outside the door are a blood-stained dress and a pair of elderly-woman's shoes. From an EXTREMELY HIGH ANGLE, we look down on Norman as he bends to pick up the stained dress and shoes. He rolls the shoes into the dress, tucks the small, neat bundle under his arm, and starts down the stairs, heading for the basement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A LONG SHOT OF THE OLD HOUSE - (NIGHT) It stands silhouetted against the sky. There is a long wait. Then, slowly, a curl of smoke comes out of the chimney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FADE IN INT. BACK ROOM OF SAM'S HARDWARE STORE IN FAIRVALE - (DAY) Sam is seated at his desk, writing a letter. Sequence begins with CAMERA IN CLOSE, over Sam's shoulder, and we can read as mush as he has written of the letter. The letterhead reads "Sam Loomis - Hardware," and the letter reads: "Dearest right-as-always Mary: I'm sitting in this tiny back room which isn't big enough for both of us, and suddenly it looks big enough for both of us. So what if we're poor and cramped and miserable, at least we'll be happy! If you haven't come to your senses, and still want to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: begins PULLING AWAY as Sam turns the sheet of paper over, continues backing away out of the small back room and heads, backwards, down the corridor, we see a young clerk, BOB SUMMERFIELD, Sam's assistant, standing behind the counter, a look of handsome patience on his face. He is waiting on a meticulous, elderly woman customer, who is holding and examining a large can of insecticide. As CAMERA PASSES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...They tell you what its ingredients are and how it's guaranteed to exterminate any insect in the world, but they do not tell you whether or not it's painless. And I say insect or man, death should always be painless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: by this has reached the front door of the hardware store and we now see a girl standing just inside the door. She is an attractive girl with a rather definite manner, a look of purposefulness. She carries a handbag and a small overnight case. She is Mary's sister, LILA CRANE. Bob Summerfield has noticed Lila, smiles brightly at her, gives her an I'll-be-with-you-in-a-moment nod. Lila starts to walk toward the counter, never taking her eyes off Bob. As she approaches, she asks quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to see Sam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam Loomis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam! Lady wants to see you! Lila looks to the back room. The woman customer goes on worriedly examining the fine print of the insecticide can. Sam comes to the door of his room, pauses, looks at Lila a moment, starts toward her, his expression indicating that he does not know her. Lila studies him with a quiet, worried expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I talk to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure... Lila glances at the customer and the clerk, turns, starts toward the front of the store. Sam holds a moment, then follows. As he reaches her, she turns, her eyes studying him intently as she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Mary's sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Mary here? Sam is mystified, and is also aware of the worried, hostile expression on Lila's face. He studies her for a quiet moment. Behind them is a display of various size carving knives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is something wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to know if my sister is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know where. In your store, somewhere in your town... anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you know? As Sam is about to speak, the Woman Customer comes sailing past, speaking as she goes and wearing a satisfied smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I can do is hope if it isn't painless, it's quick! She speaks "quick" with a kind of delicious bite, nods happily, goes on out of the store. Sam is now staring apprehensively at Lila.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To begin with, where Mary is. Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I take it you don't either? (As Lila shakes her head) How long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last Friday. She left work, and home... I was in Tucson over the weekend... I haven't heard from her, not even a phone call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you thought she'd come up here, to me? If she had, what reason would she have for not calling you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A good reason, I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well what do you think, we eloped or something? Or we're living in sin and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Loomis, you're so busy being defensive that you haven't even reacted to the most serious fact of all. Mary is missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was getting to that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing! You're putting me on the defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, if you two are in this thing together, I don't care, it's none of my business... But I want to see Mary. I want her to tell me she's all right and it's none of my business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix and... She stops, the anxiety and fear building up in her, her eyes beginning to fill with worried tears. Sam studies her for a moment, then turns and calls:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob? Run out and get yourself some lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, Sam, I brought it with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Run out and eat it. Bob gets the message, goes out through the back way. Sam goes closer to Lila, speaks with soft seriousness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What thing could we be in together?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate tears. (Takes out hankie)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Mary... in trouble?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well why didn't she come to me... call me...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not that kind... (Almost a smile) You men and your egos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind my ego. Let's talk about Mary. Their attention is distracted by a man who has strolled quietly into the room. He ignores them, walks past them, goes behind the counter, takes down a sign reading "CLOSED FOR LUNCH," walks back to the door, closes door, hangs the sign across the door window, locks the door, turns to Sam and Lila, folds his arms, smiles a particularly unfriendly smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's all talk about Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you, friend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milt Arbogast, Private Investigator. (To Lila) Where is she, Miss Crane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wouldn't have been able to tail you if you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your interest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Money. There is a moment's silence and then, unable to tolerate the sudden frightening happenings, Sam explodes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody better tell me what's going on and tell me fast! I can take so much and then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your girl friend stole forty thousand dollars. Sam looks at Arbogast in utter shock and in that state asks one of those seemingly ridiculous questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must've needed it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? (To Lila) What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was supposed to bank it, on Friday, for her boss. She didn't. And no one has seen her since.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone has seen her. Someone always sees a girl with forty thousand dollars. (To Sam) She is your girl friend, isn't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, they don't want to prosecute, they just want the money back. It was all in cash...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Casharoonie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, if she's here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She isn't! A real look of anguish comes into Lila's face. And Arbogast studies it, then speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came up here on a hunch, Miss Crane? Nothing more? No phone call... from him, or from your sister herself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not even a hunch. Just hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a little checking, I could get to believe you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care if you do or... I want to see Mary... before she gets in any deeper...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you check in Phoenix... hospitals... maybe she had an accident... a hold-up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was seen leaving town in her car. Seen by her very victims, I might add.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe it. (to Lila, slowly) Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... I just... did. The moment they told me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You might have doubted for say five minutes or so, Sister. Lila turns from Sam, a flush of guilt and regret in her face. Arbogast looks at her, quiet sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're always quickest to doubt people who have a record for being honest. I think she's here, Miss Crane. Where there's a boyfriend... (Trails off, smiles encouragingly) She won't be back there among the nuts and bolts... but she'll be in this town... somewhere. I'll find her. He nods, takes down the closed-for-lunch sign, sails it to the counter, opens door, goes out into the street. After a quiet moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just listened... and believed everything they told me. 'She stole the money.' 'We don't want to get her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the police in'...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was her boss' idea not to report it to the police?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The man whose money she... he talked so loud and fast, and I... I should've called the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He must have had a darn good reason for wanting them kept out of it... All that cash...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ought to call the police right now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Sam, is she hiding here? Are you two planning to go away with the money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could I go away? I'm in debt up to my... (Smiles at the incongruity of his reply, then goes serious) If she did steal that money...  It's hard to believe she did because it's hard to see why she would. Unless she had some wild idea that it would help me... us...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She haven't even called you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't see her... and I didn't hear from her! Believe that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to... I need to believe something. This is the first time I've ever come up against anything I couldn't... understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've led a charmed life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I just think... anything can be explained. But Mary, doing a thing like this... I don't know how to handle...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we can handle it together. (He smiles encouragingly)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came flying up here expecting to get some explanation... for all I know, she may be trying to get in touch with me, at home. I'd better go home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think she'll contact me if she contacts anybody. Why don't you stay here. When she shows up... or calls... be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to stay here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She'll need both of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where... can I stay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First rate hotel, fifty yards up the street. Come on. (as he reaches for the closed-for-lunch sign) After we check you in we'll go to the drugstore and get you a sandwich. Then we'll come back here... and wait. He hangs the sign on the door, ushers Lila out, closes door behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (A long study, her suspicion of him evaporating)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (DAY) They emerge from the store and walk along to the hotel.  As they enter, Arbogast is in the act of taking over a white Ford sedan from a rental car man. They glance at him and he returns a cynical look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Outside another hotel we see Arbogast alight from the white car and go into new hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) The white car speeding along the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Arbogast going into the office - we see the sign above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) A high shot showing the freeway and Bates house and motel on the side old highway. A pause and then across the bottom of the picture a white car speeds by on the freeway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DUSK) Another Hotel. Arbogast goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) The white car speeding along the freeway again going in the opposite direction to last time. Norman, a tiny figure, is seen going up the steps to his mother's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Arbogast's search is getting down in the scale. This is an entrance to a cheesy boarding house. "Rooms to Rent," etc. He looks at his list and then goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) The white car goes by on the freeway again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Arbogast goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TWILIGHT) Heavy traffic on the freeway. A beat or two - again the white car. It slows up opposite the distant motel. It makes a turn and goes back out of scene. A pause and it reappears on the old road and slowly makes its way toward the Bates' Motel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TWILIGHT) We now see Norman. He has brought out an old rocking chair and has placed it on the office porch and is sitting hunched in it. And he is darning one of his own socks. CAMERA HOLDS. Beyond the porch, and Norman, we see the old house and can barely make out, in the twilight dimness, the figure of his mother seated at the window. Here, too, there is that quality of quiet peace surrounded by a vague foreboding. Now Norman looks up at the SOUND of the approaching car. And continues looking as the car comes to a stop and Arbogast gets out. Arbogast gives the place a quick once-over, gazes at Norman, starts forward. In his steps and manner there is that bored, routine-logged quality of a man who has seen too many motels and asked question of too many hotel managers over too short a period of time. Norman rises as Arbogast comes forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always forget to put the sign on, but we do have vacancy. (Cheerfully) Twelve in fact. Twelve cabins, twelve vacancies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the past two days I've been to so many motels, my eyes are bleary with neon. This is the first one that looked like it was hiding from the world at large.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't really forget the sign, it just doesn't seem... any use. (Points) This used to be the main highway. (Starts for office) Want to register, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. I don't want to trouble you, just want to ask...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No trouble. Today's linen day. I change all the beds once a week, whether they've been used or not... dampness. I hate the smell of dampness. (Opening office door) It's such a dank smell. Norman is holding the door open, so Arbogast walks in. Norman follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TWILIGHT) Norman switches on the overhead light, starts for the linen closet, suddenly pauses, turns, studies Arbogast, who has remained standing by the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You out to buy a motel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I thought... you said you'd been to so many in two days...  What was it you wanted to ask?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm looking for a missing person. (takes out and opens wallet and extends it as he speaks) My name's Arbogast, private investigator... (takes back wallet when Norman doesn't look at it) Trying to trace a young girl who's been missing almost a week. From Phoenix. (A look at Norman's frightened expression) It's a private matter... family wants to forgive her... (smiles) She isn't in trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't think the police went searching for people who weren't in trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. He waits a moment, then opens closet, starts counting out sheets and pillow cases, keeps his back to Arbogast. Arbogast takes a photograph out of his pocket, talks as he crosses to Norman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have reason to believe she came this way... might have stopped in this area... (extends photograph, which Norman doesn't glance at) Did she stop here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No one has stopped here in weeks...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mind looking at the picture before committing yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Committing myself to what? You sure talk like a Policeman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at the picture. Please. Norman glances, briefly, turns away, lifts sheets and pillow cases off the shelf holds them close, almost protectively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. At least I don't recall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She might have used an alias. Mary Crane's the real name, but she might've registered...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't even bother with guests registering any more... I mean, little by little, you drop the formalities. (more relaxed, because Arbogast is listening with a pleasant smile) I shouldn't even bother to change the linen. I guess habits die hard. Which reminds me... He goes to the wall, flips a light switch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The vacancy sign. Just in case. We had a couple the other night, said if the sign hasn't been on they'd have thought this was an old deserted mining town or something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now there's a couple even remarking about your sign, and see how easily you forgot them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You thought no one has stopped here in weeks. Now, try to remember if this girl...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe she even signed the register... because habits die hard. Let's check it, huh? Norman says nothing. Arbogast goes to the desk, pulls the registry book around, flips back a page or two. Norman simply stares at the man. Arbogast hums faintly, pleasantly, as he examines the pages. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir! Marie Samuels.  Interesting alias. He takes a slip of paper out of his pocket, lays it beside the signature in the registry book, all the while nodding and smiling nicely, as if this discovery will make Norman as happy as it is making him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't know where she got "Marie," but "Samuels" figures. Her boy friend's name is Sam. (Turns to Norman, the smile gone) Was she in disguise? Or do you want to check the picture again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't lie to you. I just have trouble keeping track of... time. Arbogast has reached him, the picture extended. Norman looks dutifully at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was raining and her hair didn't look like that... damped out, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me all about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She arrived kind of late, wet and hungry and she was very tired and went right to bed and left early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How early?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very early. Dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of which morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The following morning. Sunday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one met her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or arrived with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She didn't call anyone? Even locally?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't spend the whole night with her did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Of all...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know she didn't make a call?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was tired. She said she had a long drive ahead of her, in the morning... Yes, now I'm remembering very clearly because I'm picturing. When you make a picture of the moment in your mind, you can remember every detail. She was sitting back there, no she was standing up, with some sandwich still in her hand, and she said she had to drive a long way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said she was sitting "back there," or standing rather...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. My private parlor. She had an awful hunger... so I made her some supper. And then she went to bed and left in the morning. I didn't even see her leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did she pay you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cash or check? For the cabin...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when she left, she never came back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should she? I'm sorry, I have work to do, Mr... if you don't mind...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do mind. If it don't jell, it ain't aspic! (smiles) This ain't jelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you expect me to know about... people come and go...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She isn't still here, is she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suppose I wanted to search the cabins, all twelve... would I need a warrant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, if you won't believe me, go ahead. You can help me make beds if you like. (laughs, shakes his head) Come on. He starts out. Arbogast pauses, momentarily confused by the young man's openness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Norman walks down the porch, hesitates before Cabin One, walks on a bit toward Cabin Two, stops, turns to see if Arbogast is following. Arbogast has come out onto the porch, but is not following. He has walked to the opposite end of the porch and is standing at its edge, looking up at the old house. The upstairs window is in darkness. The neon of the Vacancy and Motel signs splash strange light over the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Change your mind? Arbogast does not reply. Norman becomes apprehensive, starts to Arbogast, forcing himself to remain calm and cheerful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I've got one of those faces you can't help believing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone at home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I live there. Alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone is sitting in that window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother. Arbogast turns, gazes seriously at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's... ill. Confined to her room. It's practically living alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If this girl Mary Crane were here, you'd have no reason to hide her would you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she paid you well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, look...!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or if she had you say... gallantly protecting her... you wouldn't be fooled... you'd know she was just using you. Wouldn't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not a fool! And I'm not capable of being fooled! Not even by women!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean that as a slur on your manhood. I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all right. maybe she could have fooled me.  But... (a rueful smile) She didn't fool my mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother met her? (quickly) Can I talk to your mother?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I told you, she's confined...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just for a moment. She might have picked up a hint you'd miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sick old women are sharp. Come on, I won't disturb...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Just no!  I have one of those breaking points like any other man, believe it or not, and I'm near it. There's just so much pushing I can take and I think...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right! (starts away, toward his car, pauses) Might save me a lot of leg-work if I could just talk to your mother.  But I'd need a warrant for that, won't I? Norman does not respond. Arbogast gets in his car, starts the motor. Norman looks up, studies the man's face, his own face showing apprehension. Arbogast backs the car around very slowly, his gaze divided between the old house and the lighted window of Cabin Two. As he turns the car out, his headlights light up the porch. Norman stands, watching him drive away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Norman, but continuing to stare at the house)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) The car pulls up and Arbogast gets out of car, leaving motor running. As he starts to walk across the highway, CAMERA PULLS AWAY and we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Arbogast gets to the phone booth, enters. CAMERA STARTS FORWARD, and we see Arbogast remove a small notebook from his pocket, check on a number, drop a dime in the slot and dial this number. As we reach phone booth,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Crane, please. (listens) She leave a number? (listens) Thanks. (hangs up, dials again, waits) Lila there, Mr. Loomis? Arbogast. (waits) Lila? Look, this isn't much, but it might make you feel a little better. Mary was up here. Spent last Saturday night at Bates'  Motel, out here on the old highway. (listens) Young fellow runs it, said Mary spent the night, left, period! (listens) I did question him, believe me. I think I got all there was to get. Just have to try to pick up the scent from here. (listens) Well... maybe that's because I don't feel entirely satisfied.  He's got a sick old mother, confined type, and I think she saw Mary and talked to her. Shame, too... confined old women love to talk to strangers. (listens) I was, but I think I'll go back to the motel, first. (listens) No, you stay put, Lila. With Loomis. I should be back in an hour. (listens) All right. And Lila... You'll be happy to know what I think. I think our friend Sam Loomis didn't even know Mary was here. (smiles) See you in an hour. Or less. He hangs up, gets out of the phone booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) A distant view of the House and Motel. There is a light on in the house. There is also a light on in Norman's office. We see Norman emerge from his office and move along the porch toward the distant cabins. He carries sheets on his arm. He goes into the last cabin and switches the light on. Into the foreground the hood of the white Ford enters the scene and stops. Arbogast gets out. He goes over to the Motel office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Arbogast goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Arbogast looks around the empty office and calls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bates! He goes over to the door to the parlor and enters. He looks around the bird-ridden room. He stops short as he sees: C.U. - THE OLD SAFE IN THE CORNER C.U. - ARBOGAST goes over to it. He finds it unlocked. With a quick, cautious look around he opens it. C.U. - THE EMPTY SAFE C.U. - ARBOGAST straightens up and goes out.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE OLD SAFE IN THE CORNER C

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Arbogast comes out and looks off. He sees:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE OLD HOUSE FROM HIS VIEWPOINT

direction.raw_text: The door ajar. C.U. - ARBOGAST - (NIGHT) would go along but he stops with a new thought. He turns around and looks off. L.S. - THE OLD HOUSE FROM HIS VIEWPOINT - (NIGHT) C.U. - ARBOGAST comes to a decision. He goes off. L.S. ARBOGAST dashes up the stone steps to the House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CAMERA HOLDS as Arbogast goes up onto the porch. The house is dark within except, as we can now see, for a faint spill of light in the foyer, light which comes from the upstairs hall. Arbogast goes to the living room window, looks in, sees only darkness. Then he goes to the door, listens for along moment, hears nothing. Very slowly, almost painfully, he turns the knob of the door and pushes gently with his arm and shoulder. The door begins to open. He allows it to open just enough for him to slip through and into the foyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Arbogast gradually eases the door closed, stands against it, waiting. He looks up in the direction of the light, sees no one. The door at the head of the stairs is closed. Arbogast listens, holds his breath, hears what could be human sounds coming from upstairs but realizes these could also be the sounds of an old house after sunset. After a careful wait, he crosses to the stairs, starts up, slowly, guardedly, placing a foot squarely on each step to test it for squeaks or groans before placing his full weight on it. CAMERA FOLLOWS, remaining on floor level but TRAVELLING ALONG the stairway as Arbogast makes his way up.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A BIG HEAD OF AN ASTONISHED ARBOGAST

direction.raw_text: INT. STAIRWAY AND UPSTAIRS LANDING We see Arbogast coming up the stairs. And now we see, too, the door of the mother's room, opening, carefully and slowly. As Arbogast reaches the landing, the door opens and the mother steps out, her hand raises high, the blade of an enormous knife flashing. C.U. - A BIG HEAD OF AN ASTONISHED ARBOGAST The knife slashes across his cheek and neck. Blood spurts. The sudden attack throws him off balance. He stumbles back and staggers down the whole of the staircase. He frantically gropes for the balustrade as he goes backwards down the stairs. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him all the way. A wicked knife keeps thrusting itself into the foreground. As he collapses at the bottom, the black head and shoulders of Mrs. Bates plunges into the foreground as the CAMERA MOVES IN to contain the raising and descending murder weapon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACK ROOM OF HARDWARE STORE - (NIGHT) Lila is sitting close by the phone, and looks as if she hasn't moved from it in the last hour. Sam is pacing, occasionally stopping at the window, glancing out, pacing again. The ash tray close to Lila is filled. There is a thick atmosphere of smoke, tension and weariness in the small, otherwise cozy room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely sound. Ever notice, Lila?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam. He said an hour. Or less.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been three.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are we just going to go on sitting here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be back. Let's sit still and hang on, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hundreds! Which one is your pet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whenever I start contemplating the panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel better when you feel better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's the old highway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to run out there, bust in on Arbogast and the sick old lady, shake her up and maybe spoil everything Arbogast's been building for the last three hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arbogast said...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An hour! Or less! Sam stares at her, frowns in concern over her very real anxiety, goes to the phone, dials operator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got the number of the motel out on the old highway? Bates, I think. (waits)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam! Why call when we can go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And maybe pass Arbogast on the road? (into phone) Thanks. He presses down the receiver, releases it, dials Bates' Motel. The faint other-end ringing tones can be heard, repeatedly, annoyingly. He waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably on his way back right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, I'm going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never find it. He starts for the door. Lila follows after him into the store.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hangs up and picks up his jacket)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He pauses halfway down, turns, puts his hands on her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why can't I go out there with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... (he collects himself) One of us has to be here in case Arbogast's on the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just wait here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Contemplate your... panic button. He hurries down to the street door and out. CAMERA HOLDS on Lila as she stares after Sam. As she stands alone in the darkened store, all the hardware seems to take on sinister shapes. C.U. Among some bathroom fittings a nozzle from a shower falls onto the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lila turns and picks if from the floor and puts it back in its place. She turns and again looks to the deserted street with a touch of anxiety. She gives a slight unconscious shiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Tall and lonely still against the moonlight, the figure of Norman, silhouetted. He doesn't move, merely stands there at the edge of the swamp, staring down at the now calm and quiet face of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) All light are out, except the light in Norman's mother's room. And her figure can be seen sitting in the window, relaxed in a high-back chair, her face turned into the room. After a second, we hear the SOUND OF A MOTOR, and then Sam's small pick-up truck swings into the driveway. Sam stops the motor, automatically switches off headlights, pauses as he observes the silence and darkness of the area. Then he hops out of the cab, goes quickly to the office, knocks on the door. As he waits for a response, he looks down the long porch, studies the darkened cabins, knocks again, louder, looks in the other direction and sees the house and the figure at the one lit window. He stares a moment then calls loudly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arbogast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The silhouette of Norman. He is still. Over shot, very dimly, comes the SOUND OF SAM'S VOICE, calling again for Arbogast. Norman turns slowly until, in silhouette, we see his profile, his chin lowered furtively as he looks over his shoulder in the direction of the house. There is silence for a moment, and then again the SOUND of Sam POUNDING at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) The store is in darkness, only the glow from the back room spilling in. L.S. With CAMERA placed with its back to the street door, we can see the distant tiny figure of Lila seated and waiting in the back room beyond. There is a SOUND of a car pulling up. The tiny figure jumps up and runs all the way from the back room down the aisle of hardware and comes into a BIG HEAD. We see Lila's desperate anxious look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From her viewpoint we see Sam alighting from his truck and coming toward the door of the store. He enters. He and Lila exchange quiet glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't come back here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the old lady at home... (frowning) A sick old lady unable to answer the door... or unwilling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where could he have gone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without calling me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, he called me when he had nothing definite, nothing but a dissatisfied feeling. Don't you think he'd have called if he had anything...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I think he would have. Lila goes quiet. Sam starts toward the back room, pauses at the doorway, turns. Lila has remained by the door, looking out at the street. She feels his pause, turns, and for a moment they share at each other across the darkened room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go see Al Chambers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the Deputy Sheriff around here. As he starts forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) A dark, quiet, tree-ceilinged street, the small neat houses dim in the moonlight. Sam's pick-up truck comes down the street, pulls up before the house of Sheriff Chambers. CAMERA MOVES IN on Sam and Lila as they remain for a moment in the truck's cab, staring quietly at the sleeping house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Deputy sleeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.  Just... all the lights out... must be asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does that mean we can't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm just procrastinating.  People hate when the doorbell rings in the middle of the night. (gives up, starts out) Come on. He gets out of cab, goes around to help Lila. She is already out. CAMERA FOLLOWS them up the small path to the front door. Sam presses the bell button. Both he and Lila are almost knocked over by the shocking, clanging, ear-splitting BLAST OF THE BELL within the house, a ring which sounds more like a fire alarm than a doorbell. He tries to smile, fails. Lila doesn't even try. The downstairs hall light goes on and a moment later the door is unhesitatingly opened by MRS. CHAMBERS, a small, lively stick of a woman wrapped in a thick flannel robe and a corona of hospitality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't! (a cross look up at the bell) It's tinkerbell. (a quick smile at Lila) Al wants to be sure he'll hear it if anyone rings it in the middle of the night. (to Sam) Well come on in, at least! As she opens the door wide,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Fat roses splatter the wallpaper. The stairs are carpeted. The lighting is bright. There is a perfectly fitting wall phone by the parlor arch. Mrs. Chambers goes to the stairway, yells up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert! (a tiny wait, a smile as Sam and Lila enter) Al Chambers! Sam is about to close the door behind him. Mrs. Chambers motions for him not to, scurries across the hall, leans outside, presses the doorbell. The RING within the house is even more shattering. She closes the door, starts to the stairway, pauses as the SOUNDS of movement above COME OVER SHOT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Customers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes down the stairs, in a bathrobe which matches his wife's. He is a tall, narrow man with a face originally destined for Mount Rushmore. He nods at Sam, looks at him with wide-awake eyes and a no-nonsense concern. SAM We have a problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go out back and have some coca while the men are talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. It's my problem, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know where to start... (a look at Lila) Except at the beginning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days, looking for her sister. There's a private detective helping... and, well, we got a call tonight, from this detective, saying he'd traced Mary...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary is Lila's sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He traced her to that motel, out on the old highway...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bates' Motel. (to Lila) He has a mind like a mechanical brain and the more information you feed it... Go on, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He traced her there and called us to say he was going to question Mrs. Bates...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman took a wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. An old woman, his mother. (to Sheriff, quickly) That was early this evening. And we haven't seen or heard from him since. I went out to the motel, just got back. No one was in the office, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you help us? I think something's wrong out there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now. Your sister is missing how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She left Phoenix a week ago yesterday. And no trace until...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you and this detective come to trace her to Fairvale?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They thought she'd be coming to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Left Phoenix under her own steam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She ain't missing so much as she's run away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stole some money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forty thousand dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the police haven't been able to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone concerned thought... if they could get her to give back the money... they could avoid involving her with the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Explains the private detective. He traced her to the Bates place.  What'd he exactly say when he called you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary had been there, one night, and had left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the forty thousand dollars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't mention the money. (anxiously) What he said on the phone isn't important, is it?  He was supposed to come back after he spoke to the mother, and he didn't! That's what I want you to do something about!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go out there! Find somebody, ask some questions! (a pause) I'm sorry if I seem over-anxious to you. I keep thinking... something's wrong. I have to know what!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think something's wrong, too, Miss. But not the same thing. I think your private detective is what's wrong. (As Lila is about to object) I think he got himself a hot lead as to where your sister was going... probably from Norman Bates...  and called you to keep you still while he took off after her and the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said he was dissatisfied... and was going back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you call Norman and let him say just what happened, if he give the man a hot lead and he did just scooted off... it'll make the girl feel better, Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this hour?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was out when I was there. If he's back he probably isn't even in bed yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wasn't out when you were there. He just wasn't answering the door in the dead of night... like some people do. This fellow lives like a hermit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Recluse. Kinder word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must remember that bad business out there. About ten years ago...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've only been here five. Right now it feels like ten, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right! Then call! At least, call! Mrs. Chambers goes to phone, dials operator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Florrie, the Sheriff wants you to connect him with the Bates Motel. She hands the receiver to the Sheriff. He takes it, reluctantly, listens to the dim sound of RINGING on the other end. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman? Sheriff Chambers. (listens) Been just fine, thanks. Listen, we got some worries here. Did you have a man stop out there tonight... (listens) Well, this one wouldn't be a customer, anyway. A private detective, name of...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arbogast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arbogast. (listens) And after he left? (listens) No, it's okay, Norman. How's it been going out there? (listens) Well, I think you oughta unload that place and open up closer in to the action, a smaller place, you know... but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry I got you up, boy. Go back to sleep. Yeah, be glad to. (hangs up, turns to Mrs. Chambers) Said to give you his regards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was that all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This detective was out there and Norman told him about the girl and the detective thanked him and went away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he didn't go back? Didn't see the mother? The Sheriff looks long at Lila, shakes his head sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should've called in the police the second you found your sister has skipped. You go starting private investigations, using people you don't even know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What difference does that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Detective told you a nakedfaced lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barefaced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told you he wasn't coming right back cause he wanted to question Norman Bates' mother, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman Bates' mother has been dead and buried in Greenlawn Cemetery for the last ten years! There is a long silence. Sam and Lila stare at the Sheriff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I helped Norman pick out the dress she was buried in. Periwinkle blue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It ain't only local history, Sam, it's the only murder-and-suicide case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was... involved with, when she found out he was married, then took a helping of the same stuff herself.  Strychnine. Ugly way to die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman found them dead together.  In bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean that old woman I saw sittin' in the window wasn't Norman Bates' mother?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you saw Mary!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd know the difference between Mary and an old woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you saw an old woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! In the house behind the motel. I pounded and called but she... just ignored me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you want to tell me you saw Norman Bates' mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It must've been. Arbogast said so, too... and he said the young man wouldn't let him see her because she was ill! The Sheriff stares at both of them, and when he finally speaks there is an almost inaudible tone or irony in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if the woman up there is Mrs. Bates... who's that woman buried out at Greenlawn Cemetery?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Norman sits in the dim, one-lamp light, the phone next to him, his hand still near it as if he had not been able to move his hand after hanging up. He is staring at the shrike- like bird which is perched on the lamp shade. Decision and resolution are beginning to show in his face. Suddenly he rises, starts quickly out of the room, tries to switch off the lamp as he goes and in so doing succeeds only in knocking the bird off the shade. He watches it fall, does not try to catch it. It hits the floor with a thud and sawdust spills out. He stares sadly at it, for a moment, then tends down, scoops up the sawdust, tries to press it into the split seam, picks up the bird, puts it in a drawer. Then he puts out the lamp, goes out, crosses the darkened office and goes outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) Norman comes off the porch, walks to the path and directly up to the house, opens the door and goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman goes up, pauses one moment outside his mother's door, then opens it and goes in, leaving the door open. For a moment we hear only Norman's low, quiet voice, his words indistinguishable. Then we hear the cold shot of his mother's derisive laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sorry, boy, but you do manage to look ludicrous when you give me orders!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, mother...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! I will not hide in the fruit cellar! (A shrill laugh) Think I'm fruity, huh? (Hard, cold again) I'm staying right here!  This is my room and no one will drag me out of it... least of all my big bold son!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll come now, Mother. He came after the girl and now someone will come after him! How long do you think you can go on... Mother, please, just for a few days, just so they won't find you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just for a few days... (Furious) In that dank fruit cellar? No!  You hid me there once, boy, and you won't do it again! Not ever again!  Now get out! (A pause, quiet) I told you to get out, boy! (A longer pause) Norman! What do you think you're going to do? Don't you touch me! Don't! Norman! (A pause, then cajolingly) All right, son, put me down and I'll go. I'll go on my own two feet. I can go on my own two feet, can't I? During all this the CAMERA has been slowly creeping up the stairs. It does not stop at the top however, but continues on the same high angle that we had in Scene 57. She starts to laugh, a terrible sound like an obscene melody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll carry you, mother. Norman comes out of the room, his mother held in his arms, her head leaning against his shoulder. He carries her down the stairs, along the lower landing to the cellar stairs, and then down those stairs to the basement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (MORNING) An overcast morning, but a sunny-faced crowd. The service is just over, there is contentment, and peace, and just a little I-went-to-church-smugness in the faces of the churchgoers as they come out of the chapel, and spread their separate ways away. Amongst the crowd, waiting and searching the faces, are Sam and Lila. In their expressions there is no peace, no contentment. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE. They are not speaking. Lila looks as if she has had no sleep. Suddenly, Sam becomes alert, takes Lila's arm, starts toward the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stops as they approach Sheriff and Mrs. Chambers. The Sheriff stares rather sympathetically at Lila. Mrs. Chambers smiles nicely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd go out to the motel with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's already been.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Went out before service.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you two had breakfast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't find anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. Here, let's clear the path. He moves away and the others follow. CAMERA PANS them to the curb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he say anything about my sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just what he told your detective. She used a fake name, saw the register myself. Saw the whole place, as a matter of fact. That boy is alone there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was illusion there and I don't believe in ghosts, so there it is!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still feel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can see you do. Sorry I couldn't make you feel better. You want to come to my office this afternoon and report a missing person... And the theft, is what you want to do!  Sooner you drop this thing in the lap of the law, that's the sooner you'll stand a chance of your sister bein' picked up. How about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Sunday. Come over and do the reporting at the house, 'round dinner time. Make it nicer. You too, Sam. She smiles brightly, as if having invited them over to discuss this year's charity fandango, takes the Sheriff's arm, starts away. The Sheriff nods as he goes. Sam and Lila are alone now, at the curb, before the deserted chapel. For a long moment they just stand there, their faces as gray and overcast as the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not. Sam takes her arm, starts walking her up the street toward the spot where his pick-up truck is parked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want me to drop you at the hotel? Or you want to come over to the store? Lila does not answer. They reach the truck. Lila looks directly at Sam as he helps her into the cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't feel satisfied unless I got out there, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither will I. He slams the door, hurries around truck, gets into driver's seat, starts motor. As the truck drives off,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (PROCESS - HIGHWAY) For a moment, both are silent; Sam watching the road as if there were other cars on it, Lila staring at nothing in particular, except perhaps her own inner fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder if we'll ever see Mary again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course we will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alive. Sam looks as if he'd like to say something humorous, something to cheer her. He cannot. He remains silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We lived together all our lives. When we woke up one morning and found ourselves orphans, Mary quit college and got a job, so I could go to college.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd you go to college?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't. I got a job, too. (A pause) I wonder if that hurt her, my not letting her sacrifice for me?  Some people are so willing to suffer for you that they suffer more if you don't let them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was willing to lick the stamps. Lila looks quizzically at him, is too concerned to pursue it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder so many things about her now.  Why she never told me about you...  Funny, when you think there's an answer to everything, you think you know all the answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were going to get married. Are going to get married!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know how I found out about you? I found one of your letters... it was a nice letter, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the old highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose... when you were able to marry her she'd have presented you, all shiny and proper... she always tried to be proper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch your tenses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She always tries to be proper. Sam slows the truck to a stop, sighs, starts to light up a cigarette. Lila looks questioningly and impatiently at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You going to wait here for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going with you. But we'd better decide what we're going to say and do when we walk in...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to register. As man and wife. And get shown to a cabin... and then search every inch of that place, inside and... outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't believe it... (Starts motor) But this will be the first time I've ever pulled one of those man- and-wife-renting-cabin capers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe it. As truck starts to drive on,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) The place is empty and silent and washed dirty by the deep gray of the cloudy sky. We see Sam's truck turning into the driveway and pulling to a stop. After a moment, Sam and Lila get out of the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close on Sam and Lila as they meet on the porch side of the truck. The motel office and the house beyond can be seen in b.g. of shot. Sam and Lila merely stare for a moment, then turn and gaze up at the house. There is no figure in the window and the shade is drawn. Same goes to the office door, peers in, knocks, opens door, enters. Lila remains on the driveway, beside the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Norman standing by the window. He has pulled the curtains very slightly apart, is staring out and down at the motel, his eyes studying the lone figure of Lila, who is standing by the truck and looking up at the house.  Norman studies her, and as her eyes look up at this very window he closes the curtains, turns away. We see the suspicion and fear in his face, the surge of panic and his struggle to contain it. Then he goes away. CAMERA remains on window, shooting out and down, and through the frail curtains we can see Sam as he comes out of the motel office and joins Lila.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Unconsciously whispering) I wonder where Norman Bates does his hermiting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone was at that window. I saw the curtain move. Sam takes Lila's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. He starts with her toward the path which leads to the old house. CAMERA PANS with them, and as they turn around the office corner, they see Norman coming down the path toward them. They pause and Norman pauses. He does not smile, nor speak. His usual grin and soft friendliness are gone; containment and impassivity lie in their place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just coming up to ring for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose you want a cabin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd hoped to make it straight to San Francisco, but we don't like the look of that sky. Looks like a bad day coming... doesn't it. Norman walks past Sam, giving him the sort of quick, disapproving glance one gives a man who is obviously lying, goes onto the porch and into the office. Sam and Lila follow Norman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Norman crosses to the desk, goes behind it, takes the key to cabin number twelve off the keyboard. Sam and Lila have entered and are almost to the desk-counter by this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take you to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better sign in first, hasn't we? Sam eyes scan the counter, looking for a registration book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this trip... ninety percent business... and he wants practically notarized receipts. I better sign in and get a receipt. Norman stares at Sam, as if he'd like to yell at him, call him "liar." Instead he reaches under the desk counter, brings out the registration book. Lila moves closer, studies the book as Sam signs in. Sam signs "Joe and Mrs. Johnson."  The signature and city of "Marie Samuels" and after it, the notation "Cabin One," can be clearly seen three registrations above Sam's. When Sam has finished he closes book, hands it back to Norman. Norman does not take it, starts out from behind counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get your bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven't any.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll show you the cabin. As he starts for the door, Sam laughs. Norman stops, turns, looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First time I've seen it happen. (to Lila) Check in any place in this country without bags, and you have to pay in advance. Sam smiles as if at a funny remark, takes a bill out of his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten dollars... Norman returns to Sam, takes the extended bill, is about to start out again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That receipt...? Norman goes reluctantly behind counter, lays down the key to cabin twelve, takes a receipt book out of the drawer under counter, starts to write. Lila steps up to the desk, picks up the key, quickly, starts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll start ahead. Norman looks up, gazes her as she goes out door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Lila comes along the porch, pauses before cabin one, tries the door. It opens. She closes it quickly as she hears Sam and Norman coming out of the motel office, continues on down the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't bother yourself... we'll find it. He goes on down the porch, doesn't even glance at cabin one, walks quickly and catches up to Lila just as she reaches cabin twelve. CAMERA REMAINS with Norman, who is standing by the office door, looking after Sam and Lila, his face alert and no longer impassive. He waits a moment, after they have closed their cabin door, then crosses to the pickup truck. CAMERA MOVES with him. He studies the truck, then leans in through the driver's window, twists the registration card around, reads it. It gives the correct name and address of Sam Loomis. Norman comes back out of the window, glances once more toward cabin twelve, then at the old house. His suspicions are confirmed, and now there is the relaxation of relief in his face. He takes on a purposeful air, turns, strides up the path, up onto the porch of the house, opens the door, goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Lila is at the cabin's rear window, looking out, straining for a glimpse of the old house, which cannot be seen from the window of this cabin. She turns, frustrated, anxious. Sam is standing at the foot of the bed, staring at the smooth coverlet, his brow creased in a sadness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should have asked for Cabin One... The one Mary was in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad we didn't. He pulls his eyes from the bed, crosses to the desk, sits wearily, lights a cigarette. Lila watches him for a moment, feels a real compassion, goes to the bed, sits on its edge, turns again and looks at Sam's back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to go into that cabin and search it, Sam... no matter what we're afraid of finding and no matter how much it may hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. (A pause) Do you think if something happened, it happened there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, if you owned a useless business like this motel... one you probably couldn't even sell...  what would you need to get away, to start a new business, somewhere else? (As Sam studies her) Forty thousand dollars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could we prove... (An almost hopeless laugh) Well, if he opens a new motel on the new highway... say, a year from now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There must be some proof that exists right now! Something that proves he got that money away from Mary... Some way!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you sound so certain?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arbogast! Sam, he liked me... or felt sorry for me... and he was starting to feel the same about you. I heard it when he called... in his voice, a caring. He wouldn't have gone anywhere or done anything without telling us.  Unless he was stopped. And he was stopped, so he must have found out something! Sam considers a moment, nods agreement, rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll start with Cabin One. He goes to the door, opens it slightly, looks out, then, back to Lila:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he sees us... we're just taking the air. Lila goes to the door. He holds it open and she goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) Sam closes the door, joins Lila, takes her hand. Together they walk along the porch in the direction of Cabin One. CAMERA FOLLOWS. They pause before the door of Cabin One. Sam motions Lila to wait, to hold still, then goes on to the office, opens the door, calls in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bates? He waits, there is no response. He goes in and in a moment comes back out, closes the door, goes to Lila. She has already opened the door of Cabin One and has started to enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (DAY) The blinds are closed and the room is almost night-dark. Sam comes in after Lila, closes the door behind him. For a moment they just gaze at the room, as if willing it to tell them some satisfactory story. Neither speaks. Then, in dark silence, they begin to search, going methodically and thoroughly through all drawers, the closet, the desk, searching under the bed and in dark corners, not knowing what they expect to find and yet expecting to find some thing. Lila opens the bathroom door, looks in. The windowless room is very dark. She switches on the light, goes in. Sam moves toward the bathroom, is about to follow her in when he notices which room it is and automatically catches himself up, backs out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hospital clean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bathroom. Look at how clean it is. The one in our cabin is clean... but this is clean! Sam goes in, glances around, nods. Lila goes through the medicine cabinet, finds nothing but a glass and two tiny tabs of soap. Sam leans against the door-jamb, looks at the tub, the shower pipe above it. He continues to stare, more interested suddenly, as if bothered by some off-key evidence he can't put his finger on. Then he looks at the shower curtain rod. And realizes there is no shower curtain. He frowns, is about to say something when Lila, who has been momentarily out of shot, interrupts. Sam turns, CAMERA TURNS, and we see Lila is standing above the toilet bowl, a tiny piece of wet paper stuck to the tip of her right index finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It didn't get washed down. It's figuring... the kind you tear up and get rid of. (Extending her finger toward Sam) Some figure has been added to or subtracted from... forty thousand. Sam lifts the piece of paper off her finger, studies it, takes out his wallet, presses the wet scrap to his driver's license shield, puts it back in the wallet and puts the wallet away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's proof Mary was here!  It would be too wild a coincidence for somebody else to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bates never denied Mary was here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (A thought) But maybe this proves that Bates found out about the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do we simply ask him where he's hidden it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, that old woman, whoever she is. I think she told Arbogast something! And I want her to tell us the same thing! She starts out of the bathroom. Sam takes hold of her arm, stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't go up there.
